Articles.Content: Yup, made drop pod and couple of rovers. No pics, 'coz apparently i'm too lazy to learn how to post them on interwebs. Success was...moderate. Drop pod placed on top of the rocket made it behave like a rover - flying was almost impossible. I got to about 11 km and separated, after that it was leisure floating down on a parachute. Rovers behaved better, but i'm still fiddling with wheel placement. Too high, and they flip on any bump. Too low, and wheels sink in the ground and refuse to move. More testing is needed. I'm thinking maybe adding some cubic protrusions on the front and rear could make placing wheels easier?

Kris

I only partially understand cfgs, so thats a big help. I did think about making this part a pod, but I decided that adding a dashboard part as a pod might be interesting.

I'll test this out, it should be good till I get a dashboard model done.

Thanks Kris:D

Don't make it a pod, cuz no one actually sits in it, it's clearly a structural piece...

Countrykris, Breaking force and torque have nothing to do with wheels they are related to structural damage, like if you crash.

I have to say, I have been looking for a long time for a good structural base for rovers, this isn't quite there yet due to the wheels not fitting right, but it is certainly the best thing I have found, and I can tell you are fixing it.

So thank you thank you soo soo much. .

Ass I said i'm not a modder just like to tweak things for my own use. All so just trying to help. I understand it is a structural piece, but his main idea was to reduce part count, witch I would to like to do. By making it a pod that's one more less part needed.
Here is what I have got so far.

Don't make it a pod, cuz no one actually sits in it, that would be silly, it's clearly a structural piece... it works just like any other structural piece that you use seats with.

Countrykris, Breaking force and torque have nothing to do with wheels they are related to structural damage, like if you crash.

I have to say, I have been looking for a long time for a good structural base for rovers, this isn't quite there yet due to the wheels not fitting right, but it is certainly the best thing I have found, and I can tell you are fixing it.

So thank you thank you soo soo much.

Thanks to all for the encouragement, comments and suggestions. Everyone builds stuff differently so its great to hear all these different opinions.

My best regards to all

Angus.

Actually, it would make sense as an unmanned pod. There is often a need to make a rover capable of unmanned motion, anyway.

Structural works fine too, though, but unmanned pod would save a part.

P.S. Also, please don't duplicate models between parts. With GameData's part config loading, you can have the same model file and different textures for every part and save memory. If everyone does it, everyone will be happier in the end.

I haven't actually had a chance to really play since page one of this thread, so I just got around to doing anything with the batch of these I downloaded then, but it worked out great

Everything not stock is B9 except the three barely visible hexcans powering the cart behind Jeb

I made one modification to the cfgs, adding attachment nodes positioned roughly inside the tubes on either side, at the bottom, lined up with the regular bottom node. I used them to attach the two B9 triangle panels that act as vague doors. When I remember to deactivate steering on the rear wheels it's stable as all hell, I even flipped it lengthwise once and didn't break anything. Only once.

Other than perhaps the tubes having too many sides for how small they are and that messing with placing things onto them, I haven't had any problem with the collider; as long as I put something on the roof so it doesn't pretend to be a convertable.

Attachable door parts matched to the opening would be really cool; especially if they were animated to open in some way. It'd also be helpful to have a windshield for Jeb to epically fly through when he crashes, or maybe not fly through when he crashes.
